Description: Fragment of a marble ovolo moulding with cove edge. Small fragment of a 2,1 cm thick and straight ovolo moulding, which has a flat lower site and has on the right a rectangular cut and flat joint area. On the front side a rim sets into a profound cove. Traces of blue paint. Light grey and glazed polished marble. The left and the backside are fractured.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: According to Pryce there were traces of blue paint visible (Pryce 1999, Cat. Br. Mus.), however, they are no longer preserved. Due to the straight lines and the joint area only two interpretations are possible: the ovolo moulding belongs either to the bottom of a volute acroterion of an altar, which would be double as thick as the moulding of fragment B 419, or it was a mending piece for a middle sized Ionic capital. The latter is very unlikely (Koenigs 2007).
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B428)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.35, p.337, fig. 6.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.44) (Phase 3)
